channel.title: Bytecode lib
channel.description:
Hmm, a while back I was working on a bytecode library, and I'm going to resume working on it, but I'm thinking of redoing it because I want to implement some features and such I didn't consider at first. However, I have 1 question...
The library will be used in a scripting environment by people, would it be best to give them direct access to the constant pool like BCEL or keep all data related to certain object with the object like ASM? I was thinking of doing the latter by reading the java files and adding all of the read data to their respective objects, and when saving building a new constantpool, I'd also add methods like hasLDC or something so any need of having access to the constantpool would be averted...

item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:43, topic:335517”]I have looked at FPC, but it’s been a few years ago and I remember then it was in really bad condition. Hopefully it is better now, it couldn’t have gotten much worse.

I also wasn’t aware Delphi wasn’t ran by borland anymore, that is probably a good thing.[/quote]
Yeah, FPC was in pretty bad shape, but it has improved a lot, though I wouldn’t quite use it actively yet, it’s getting there. Though I don’t see companies like DevExpress and such supporting it any time soon…

And yeah, Borland was pretty horrible, though Embarcadero is certainly equally ambitious, but their approach to everything is a lot better. Borland always tried to do too much at once in too little time with too little people, Embarcadero gradually takes on problems and makes new things so everything goes a lot more smoothly and they don’t end up with half-assed products. They also realized it was pretty stupid for Borland to try to compete with Microsoft with Delphi.NET, which was a half-assed cross-breed between Delphi and .NET, they tried to make it as much like the native Delphi as they could, which was a huge mistake and lead to the fact that rly no one used it. Embarcadero has since Delphi 2009 dropped the product and moved on to Delphi Prism, which is a .NET implementation of pascal, but not compatible with Delphi like Borland tried with Delphi.NET. Also Prism integrates in Visual studio rather than to be integrated into the Delphi IDE like Delphi.NET was. Which I think is pretty great, since the Delphi IDE was never intended for a .NET language… Prism is powered by the RemObjects Oxygene compiler technology, which is pretty great, it cares somewhat less about being conform with normal pascal syntax to ensure that it doesn’t hold back on language features. Though my license includes it, I don’t use Prism myself, the nice thing is that it does allow you to use Mono, so you can do cross-platform development with it, if you like Pascal/Delphi and .NET, it’s nice to check out. http://www.embarcadero.com/products/delphi-prism

item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:41, topic:335517”]Closed source, proprietary languages are ALWAYS going to fall behind open source, free languages, it is just a fact. I would never pay for a compiler, the free ones are so much better. Also, in these days of a variety of operating systems and new platforms (some of which are smart phones, netbooks, tablets etc etc) a language (or library, for that matter) that is locked to one platform is just ridiculous to develop apps on and I’d never even consider it.

That being said, I do like the syntax of pascal but the lack of a good, modern, free and open source compiler makes me never use it.

Also, languages that lock you to a single IDE suck as well. Choice is great and drives innovation and new, helpful features. A company like borland who has the monopoly on delphi has no reason to improve it, as a delphi dev you are already locked in.

@topic, I agree that everything should be abstracted and hidden from the user, but honestly this may be the wrong forum, because no matter how awesome your bytecode library is, no one here will use it. (if it was C or C++, it would be an entirely different story)[/quote]
True, open-source does have a lot of advantages… And Delphi certainly has plenty of cons, I won’t argue there, when Embarcadero took over from Borland, they had a lot of damage to fix, by the time Delphi reached version 2007 it had become entirely unstable. There’s still a long way to go before it’s perfect, but they’re getting there…

Well, Lazarus (FPC) is an open-source alternative to Delphi, it’s not all that good though unfortunately, it still needs loads of work, but on the other side, more and more component developers for Delphi are starting to support the platform…

One plus side to Delphi that I think is pretty nice is that Embarcadero is very close to the community, they listen to the needs of their users, trough their community, surveys, etc… They also work very closely with component developers to both make sure that the components are up-to-date with the latest changes to the language and to get good ideas on how to improve the language further. Not the same as open-source, but I think it does help a lot…

@topic, true, this may be the wrong forum, but I just wanted an opinion on how I should structure my library, nothing more, I figured that people in here would have better knowledge about the topic.

[quote=“BAsh, post:35, topic:335517”][quote author=Freddy1990 link=topic=431896.msg3171497#msg3171497 date=1270483075]
Also, get your facts straight. An academic Delphi licenses is sold for as little as €121 and Delphi documentation has improved a lot over the years, try to keep up.
[/quote]
Thats okay then. Please continue.[/quote]
I wrote a topic about Delphi at cruels.net a while back about the modern day Delphi and why it’s a good choice as a programming language. Here’s some of the features I listed:

Language features:

  • Extensive backwards compatibility
  • Pointers
  • Inline ASM
  • Interfaces
  • Generics
  • Class constructors/destructors/variables/methods (shared/static members)
  • Inlining
  • Database support (blackfishsql, datasnap, asa, ase, db2, firebird, informix, interbase, mssql, mysql, oracle, …)
  • Large included component library with full support for all new Windows 7 features
  • OOP
  • for…in loops (foreach)
  • Advanced RTTI support
  • Unicode support
  • Delayed loading of dll functions
  • Scoped enumerators (If flag is set for backwards compatibility)
  • Support for Direct2D in Windows 7
  • Components for mouse gestures and touch interfaces
  • Easy threading
  • Anonymous methods
  • Deprecated directive (with comment support)
  • Exit with a value (similar to return in c++)
  • Overloading
  • Abstract classes/class members
  • ToString, Equals, UnitName in objects
  • Operator overloading
  • StringBuilder, Readers/Writers, Streams
  • Advanced error handling
  • Included Indy library with components for loads of connection protocols with SSL support
  • ActiveX controls
  • OLE automation
  • Linking object files from C++ builder to compile C++ code into Delphi projects to wrap C++ libraries

IDE features:

  • Refactoring
  • Code folding with regions
  • Code hints
  • Code completion
  • Block completion
  • Database viewers
  • Fast search bar rather than dialog with regex support
  • Searching in project/open files/one or more directories with regex support
  • Debugging capabilities for individual threads
  • IDE Insight (Quick access to anything in the IDE)
  • Open tools API (Allows you to modify the IDE and it’s features)
  • Block editing (SyncEdit)
  • Class explorer
  • Modeling tools
  • Debugging tools (breakpoints, watches, cpu views, memory views, stacktraces, disassembly view, …)
  • Live templates
  • History (basic local version control system)
  • Visual development with DFM linking (forms are stored in a DFM file instead of code being generated for them)
  • Line change indicators
  • Test unit support (DUnit)

You can view visual representations of a few of the IDE features here, the article is quite old though, it doesn’t show loads of newer features: http://edn.embarcadero.com/article/34323

There’s loads of stuff I fail to mention of course. Only thing I miss are lambda expressions…
